Aim to get explicit consent from users (e.g. via forms or SMS) before marketing calls especially as data privacy laws evolve. AI calls are not common in BD – if used ensure they clearly identify the business and provide a way to connect to a human or opt out.

notes.existing_relationship: No blanket ER exemption in PDPO – even existing customers had to be informed and given opt-out chance before marketing. **However** service-related calls (not marketing new products) are allowed. Existing customers who haven't opted out can be called but must stop if they opt out
notes.callerid_rules: No special caller ID rules for telemarketing yet (proposed law would ban hiding number). It's best practice to display a valid Hong Kong number and identify the organization during the call. (Since 2015 incoming overseas calls show "+" prefix to help identify scams)
notes.exceptions: Charity solicitations and purely service calls are not "direct marketing" under PDPO. **Unsolicited recorded calls faxes SMS** are covered by UEMO (with DNC lists) but live person-to-person calls are currently unregulated by UEMO. sources.legal_source: PDPO (EN) OFCA DNC Guidelines (EN) PCPD Direct Marketing Guidelines (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** No universal DNC for live calls yet but **do NOT cold-call HK numbers without prior PDPO compliance**. Ensure you have either (a) the person's consent or (b) have given them a PDPO notice and an opportunity to opt out (e.g. via email/SMS) before calling. Maintain an internal DNC list per PDPO (if someone says "don't call me again" record and honor that). Avoid call attempts at night (common courtesy; industry practice is roughly 9am–9pm). Monitor legislative developments – a P2P DNC registry could become law; if it does integrate it immediately. AI voice calls can be used but **do not conceal identity** – start with a clear introduction as required.

b2c.description: Opt-out (Default opt-out via National DND registry; can only call if number not on DND or consumer opted in to your messages)

dnc.name: National Customer Preference Register (NCPR) a.k.a. **"Do Not Disturb" registry**

notes.existing_relationship: No general ER exemption. **Even if the person is a recent customer you cannot bypass DND rules**. TRAI allows exceptions only if the user has themselves toggled categories to receive certain calls (or given explicit consent via verified means)
notes.callerid_rules: **Must use designated telemarketer numbers (140xx series)** for all outbound marketing calls. CLI cannot be spoofed; using personal/mobile SIMs for telemarketing is illegal (telcos will disconnect unregistered sources on complaint). All marketing SMS must use registered sender IDs and templates
notes.exceptions: Transactional calls (order confirmations delivery info) are exempt from "commercial communication" rules if purely service and not promotional. Certain sectors use **promotional category preferences** (e.g. a user might allow bank-related promos but block others). Political survey calls are not covered by TRAI's telemarketing rules but may be subject to Election Commission codes

sources.legal_source: TRAI UCC Rules (EN) NCPR Portal (EN) DPDPA 2023 (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** **Absolutely integrate the DND list**: scrub every outbound number against India's NCPR. Only dial via registered telemarketer IDs and on **140xx numbers**. Enforce time-of-day rules (no promotional dialing between 9pm–9am India time). Implement category-based opt-outs if applicable (TRAI allows users to opt in to some categories and out of others). Obtain express consent (digitally or in writing) for any automated or bulk calling campaigns – TRAI mandates recent (within 3 months) consent for commercial calls. Recording calls isn't mandated but keep logs and recordings of consent where possible (for compliance defense). AI voice agents can be used but they must follow all rules: use approved caller ID state the business identity at start and include an opt-out (e.g. "Press 9 to unsubscribe") in the script.

b2c.description: Opt-in (implied by PDP Act – explicit consent is required to use personal data like phone numbers for marketing). Traditionally opt-out in practice (many cold calls happen) but new law leans toward consent

b2b.description: No formal regime; in practice B2B marketing calls are common and not specifically regulated but prudent to apply PDP consent if personal info is used

notes.callerid_rules: No special telemarketer caller IDs. Regulators encourage carriers to label spam calls (via apps or network) but no prefix. Caller ID must not be spoofed (prohibited by law due to fraud concerns)
notes.exceptions: Certain types of calls are not considered "marketing" – e.g. collection calls purely informational service calls. Those are permitted without consent for that specific purpose. Otherwise little in the way of exceptions; all promotional calls are covered by data protection and consumer laws

sources.legal_source: Personal Data Protection Act No.27 of 2022 (ID) (ID) OJK Guidelines (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** After Indonesia's PDP law **do not cold-call without prior consent**. You should obtain clear consent (e.g. web form tick box) before calling Indonesian consumers. Maintain proof of consent for each contact. Ensure a privacy notice is given (if calling agents should mention how you got their number). For any call lists you had pre-law consider running a re-consent campaign. Timing: stick to local business hours. Train agents for polite handling – unwanted calls can be reported to Kominfo or Consumer Protection. Use of AI voice: not specifically banned but given low public familiarity it could be poorly received – if used immediately allow option to speak to a human. Keep recordings secure and document consent withdrawal promptly.

sources.legal_source: Specified Commercial Transactions Act (EN) APPI (EN) Consumer Affairs Agency Guidelines (JA)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** No national DNC list – but **internal opt-out** is mandatory. System should allow agents to instantly mark a number as "do-not-call" if the person refuses and no further calls to that consumer. Avoid calling outside 8am–9pm local time. Ensure caller ID is shown and agents give a proper intro. Recording okay (one-party consent) but best practice is to inform ("this call may be recorded…"). AI voices can be used; no disclosure rule but do not mislead or impersonate a human. Provide an opt-out mechanism during any automated call to comply with fair practice.

b2b.description: No consent needed for B2B context under PDPA (unless calling someone's personal number). Ethical opt-out if requested

dnc.name: None (no centralized DNC registry; companies rely on PDPA's opt-out rights)

notes.existing_relationship: No special exemption. If someone is an existing customer you still must comply with PDPA notice/consent unless it's *strictly related to the product they bought*. Many companies include a PDPA consent clause in customer forms to cover future marketing
notes.callerid_rules: No specific caller ID rules for telemarketers. Usually calls originate from mobile or fixed numbers. The MCMC has encouraged truthful CLI and taken action on scam call CLI spoofing but no dedicated prefix like "+AD" exists. Always display a number; do not spoof
notes.exceptions: Service-related calls (e.g. appointment reminders) are not "marketing" and are allowed without separate consent. Political and charitable calls are outside PDPA (which covers commercial context). PDPA only applies to personal data – so truly anonymous marketing (cold-calling random numbers without personal info) is a grey area but not common practice

sources.notes: **Product Note:** Ensure **PDPA compliance**: you should have either explicit consent or have provided a privacy notice with an opt-out opportunity *before* calling Malaysian individuals. If you haven't your calls could be unlawful. A practical approach is to send an email/SMS asking permission or include consent in web sign-ups. Always allow opt-out (like an internal DNC): if someone says "don't call" mark it and don't call again. Time your calls considerately. Although no formal DNC list the PDPA opt-out right functions similarly – be ready to delete or suppress data of anyone who objects to marketing. Keep call logs to show compliance (in case of complaints to PDPC). AI voice use: permissible but ensure it follows PDPA (the call content is personal data processing); it's wise to have the AI state which company it represents and offer a human fallback.

b2c.description: Opt-in/Consent likely required for unsolicited marketing under privacy law (Data Protection Act) – though enforcement is nascent

b2b.description: Opt-in not required for pure B2B context (ensure the number isn't personal)

notes.existing_relationship: No formal exemption. Even for existing customers best to get consent or at least ensure they haven't objected (per Data Protection Act requirements for direct marketing)
notes.callerid_rules: No known caller ID or prefix requirements. Use a local recognizable number for better response. (Maldives telecom providers do not distinguish telemarketing lines)
notes.exceptions: N/A – no documented exceptions. Political campaign calls might be subject to electoral guidelines but no telemarketing rules per se

sources.notes: **Product Note:** Given the new privacy law treat Maldives as **opt-in territory**: do not cold-call individuals without prior consent. If calls are made ensure you have a lawful basis (preferably consent). There's no DNC list so manage opt-outs internally. Because the market is small unsolicited calls can cause brand damage quickly. Focus on consent-based outreach (e.g. customers who signed up). AI calls are untested here – use with caution and clearly identify the caller to avoid confusion or hang-ups.

sources.notes: **Product Note:** Very little formal guidance. If engaging in telemarketing in Mongolia follow best practices: get prior permission where possible introduce yourself clearly and keep an internal list of anyone who says stop. Given the lack of rules telemarketing could be seen as unusual – a gentle personalized approach is key. Keep volumes low to avoid prompting regulatory attention. AI calls are untested – if used make them sound as natural and polite as possible or prefer live agents.
No marketing law; heavy telecom surveillance exists.

notes.exceptions: N/A – no known exceptions beyond regular practice (e.g. government/public safety calls aren't marketing). Essentially all unsolicited sales calls are tolerated unless they become harassment

sources.notes: **Product Note:** **No clear legal framework** – proceed conservatively. Always allow recipients to opt out and maintain an internal list of "do-not-call" requests. Limit call frequency to avoid being flagged for nuisance. If Nepal enacts its data protection law (draft pending) expect a consent/opt-out requirement for using personal numbers. Until then apply basic etiquette: identify your company on calls offer a way to decline future calls and stick to local business hours. AI calls: since unregulated ensure they aren't mistaken for scams – perhaps open with a statement and route to human on request.

dnc.name: Do Not Call Register (DNCR)
dnc.url: No public website; opt-out via SMS "reg" to 3627 (PTA service)

notes.existing_relationship: No formal ER exemption. If a customer's number is on DNCR you cannot legally telemarket to them. Companies should maintain internal do-not-call lists as well. Transactional calls to existing customers (e.g. service updates) are allowed
notes.callerid_rules: No special caller ID or prefix system (unlike India). Telemarketers often use regular mobile or landline numbers; PTA warns operators to curb **SPAM CLI** and allows users to block unknown numbers via *420#. (Product should ensure valid Pakistani numbers are displayed; best practice: use identifiable numbers and avoid frequent number changes)
notes.exceptions: Messages from charities or political campaigns are not explicitly covered by the DNCR (the DNCR is aimed at "telemarketing-related messages"). PTA's focus is on commercial promotions. Also truly "transactional" service calls aren't considered telemarketing. **Note:** Enforcement is via carrier filtering and user complaints so compliance relies on telecom cooperation

sources.legal_source: PTA DNCR Guidelines (EN) PTA Anti-Spam Measures (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** Enable **Pakistan DNCR compliance**: do not contact numbers that have opted out via 3627 (telecom operators likely filter such numbers – nonetheless maintain your own list of numbers to avoid). Provide a clear opt-out method in any message or call. It's advisable to get **opt-in consent** especially for bulk campaigns as Pakistan may introduce data protection soon. Limit call times to business hours/local daytime to avoid complaints. Monitor PTA guidelines – they sometimes issue new spam-control directives (e.g. forbidding masking of identities or requiring telemarketer registration). Automated/AI calls should be used sparingly and always include identification and opt-out (to avoid being flagged as spam).

b2c.description: Opt-in (implied by Data Privacy Act – organizations should have consent to use personal info for marketing calls; at minimum an opt-out mechanism must be provided if they rely on legitimate interest)

notes.existing_relationship: No explicit ER exemption. If the person didn't opt in being a customer doesn't automatically allow marketing calls. However if they provided their number during a transaction some companies assume "legitimate interest" for similar offers – this is a gray area; NPC would likely favor explicit consent for marketing
notes.callerid_rules: No special telemarketer caller ID rules. Often calls come from mobile numbers. Telecoms have implemented caller ID tagging for spam (some networks show "Spam Likely"). The National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) has regulations against caller ID spoofing (to combat scams) but no prefix system for marketing
notes.exceptions: Non-commercial calls (surveys political) aren't covered by the marketing consent requirement of DPA. But fraudulent/spoof calls are separately illegal. Otherwise all promotional calls must follow privacy principles

sources.legal_source: Data Privacy Act IRR 2016 (EN) NPC Advisory on Direct Marketing 2017 (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** Operate under the assumption of **consent required**. Ideally call only those who have opted in via web forms etc. If you must cold-call ensure you give a proper privacy notice in the call (who you are how you got their number if asked and that they can opt out). Immediately cease calling a number if the person objects – and add it to an internal DNC list. Be mindful the Philippines is very sensitive to scam calls; using an AI voice might confuse people – better to use a live agent for initial contact. Keep call times to business hours. Stay alert for a potential DNC law; if one passes compliance (scrubbing against it) will become mandatory.

notes.existing_relationship: Existing relationship does not remove duties (identification/consent/opt-out).

b2b.description: No opt-in needed for genuine B2B context. **However** if calling a person's mobile (even for business) it's safer to treat under PDPA and check DNC unless you confirm it's not a personal number

dnc.name: **Do Not Call Registry** (covers calls SMS fax)

notes.existing_relationship: No general exemption. **Even customer numbers must be checked against DNC unless you have documented consent**. PDPC allows organizations to obtain "express consent" to bypass DNC – e.g. a customer ticking a box "I agree to calls" – which then permits calls even if they're on DNC
notes.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be concealed. There's no special prefix but many marketing calls originate from mobile-prefix numbers which recipients often distrust. Under new anti-scam measures telemarketers using overseas routes must use "[+]-prefix" (this is for all overseas calls). Locally the new requirement (2023) is that spoofed local numbers are forbidden – use the number assigned to you. **In short:** use a valid SG number and don't mask CLI
notes.exceptions: Pure service calls (e.g. password reset calls) aren't "telemarketing". Likewise survey or market research calls are excluded if no selling involved. The DNC registry specifically covers marketing of goods/services. Non-commercial and transactional messages are exempt

sources.legal_source: PDPA (EN) PDPC DNC Guidelines (EN) PDPC Advisory Guidelines on DNC Provisions 2021 (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** **Must integrate SG's DNC registry**. Before any call or text to a Singapore number check if it's on DNC (unless you've obtained explicit consent within the last *likely* 12 months – PDPC recommends refreshing consent). Maintain records of consent (in case of audit). Include the organization's name and contact in call or immediately after (legal requirement). Ensure caller ID is displayed; ideally use a Singapore number to avoid "[SPAM?]" labeling. If an agent or AI reaches voicemail they should state the organization and callback info to comply with PDPC rules. Timing: stick to local waking hours to avoid "nuisance" interpretations. AI voice usage is allowed but if you use a prerecorded message **provide a way to opt-out (e.g. "press 9 to be removed")** in the call.

b2c.description: Opt-in effectively required – **prior consent** needed for marketing calls; consumers can opt out via DNC registry

b2b.description: No formal opt-in/out for B2B but prudent to treat as opt-out if individuals' data is involved

notes.existing_relationship: No broad ER exemption. **If number is on DNC you cannot call even if they are a customer**. However if a customer gave explicit consent for certain calls that consent overrides DNC for those calls
notes.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be spoofed; **telemarketers must use a valid number** and cannot hide it. No special prefix by law but calls often flagged "Advertisement" on phones. (Carriers block masked/spoofed calls under Telecom Act)
notes.exceptions: Pure service or transactional calls (e.g. flight cancellation notices) are not "marketing" and not subject to DNC. **Political or survey calls** are outside telemarketing law. Telemarketing rules apply only to sales/advertising calls

sources.legal_source: KFTC DNC Registry (EN) PIPA (EN) Door-to-Door Sales Act (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** Must integrate with the **KFTC DNC registry** – before dialing any KR consumer number check against donotcall.go.kr (API available). Ensure **prior consent** is obtained for marketing calls (document it). Provide disclosure of data source upon request (Korean law requires telling the person how you got their number). Dial only within standard hours (8am–9pm local). Use only approved phone numbers (get a 140-type telemarketing number if available in KR). Recording can be enabled (one-party consent) and is required if selling insurance/financial products – so have recording on for those campaigns.

notes.exceptions: If the call is purely informational (not marketing) it's not restricted. Political campaign calls charity calls are not addressed by current laws and generally permissible. The Data Protection Act focuses on **"commercial" use of personal data** – so nonprofit communications may not be affected

sources.legal_source: Data Protection Act No. 9 of 2022 (official gazette) (EN)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** Implement basic **opt-out handling**: allow Sri Lankan recipients to easily opt out of future calls (and honor that in your system). Given the new privacy law it's safest to use **consent-based marketing** – i.e. call people who have agreed or not objected after notice. Train agents to immediately comply if a person says they don't want marketing. Keep call times to normal hours. Because no official DNC exists err on side of caution: perhaps avoid repeatedly cold-calling non-customers. Keep an eye on any consumer protection updates – if telemarketing nuisances rise regulations could be introduced. AI voice calls should follow the same norms as human calls (clear identification etc.).

notes.exceptions: Certain sectors (e.g. finance) have specific rules: banks must stop marketing if customer says so (regulated by financial authorities). Also **7-day cooling-off** period applies to purchases made via telemarketing (distance sale)

sources.legal_source: Fair Trade Act (ZH) PDPA (ZH) Consumer Protection Act (ZH)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** Implement **per-number opt-out tracking**. Agents/scripts must inform consumers of the sales intent and **stop immediately if the consumer expresses disinterest**. Configure dialer to block any number that opted out ("拒絕行銷"). Ensure caller ID is never withheld. Allow call recording especially to capture the agreement for any sale (required to keep as proof). AI calls are not explicitly regulated but all the same rules (identification opt-out option etc.) apply. Err on the side of consent: consider obtaining explicit opt-in for marketing calls when possible due to PDPA's privacy expectations.

notes.callerid_rules: No dedicated caller ID rules for telemarketers yet. The National Telecom Commission has encouraged carriers to label spam numbers and introduced a prefix "<ADV>" tag for SMS marketing. For calls new measures in 2023 require telecom operators to display a "Scam warning" on suspicious call numbers. Telemarketers should use numbers registered in their company name; avoid frequent number changes (could be flagged)
notes.exceptions: Government informational calls (e.g. public health) aren't considered marketing. Apart from that **virtually no exceptions** – any commercial promotion triggers PDPA. The telecom regulator NBTC has separate rules for prize promotion calls/SMS (lottery scams) but those outlaw fraud rather than allow exceptions

sources.legal_source: PDPA B.E.2562 (2019) (TH) Thai PDPC Guidance (EN summary)
sources.notes: **Product Note:** Treat Thailand as **consent-required**. Ensure you have explicit opt-in (e.g. checked box "I agree to be contacted") before cold-calling a Thai individual. Keep proof of consent. Without consent you risk PDPC penalties. Implement internal suppression: if anyone says they didn't consent or asks not to be called stop immediately and log it. Monitor legal developments – a formal DNC list may appear; if so integrate it. Use clearly identified phone numbers (matching your company) for calls – this builds trust and avoids being auto-flagged. AI calls: Use cautiously; Thais have been hit with scam robocalls so an unfamiliar AI voice might be mistaken for a scam. If you do use an AI consider a Thai-language intro that it's an automated call from Company X and offer a human agent option.
